channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Mexico's first female president; a Georgia cancer patient's Medicaid struggle
item.description: Mexico makes history with its first female president. How an extra $30 a month kept a cancer patient from qualifying for Medicaid.
item.content:encoded:
Mexico makes history with its first female president. How an extra $30 a month kept a cancer patient from qualifying for Medicaid.

(Image credit: Eduardo Verdugo)

item.title: Hunter Biden to go on trial on gun charges
item.description: The trial, which opens Monday in federal court in Delaware with jury selection, is the first of two cases brought by Justice Department special counsel David Weiss against the president’s son.
item.content:encoded:
The trial, which opens Monday in federal court in Delaware with jury selection, is the first of two cases brought by Justice Department special counsel David Weiss against the president’s son.

(Image credit: Kent Nishimura
)
item.dc:creator: Ryan Lucas

item.title: Step aside BMI, body composition tests are on the rise. Here's what to know
item.description: If you dread getting on a scale to calculate your body mass index, there’s a good reason to ignore the measure. Body composition tests are an increasingly popular way to gauge health. Here’s why they're better than BMI.
item.content:encoded:
If you dread getting on a scale to calculate your body mass index, there’s a good reason to ignore the measure. Body composition tests are an increasingly popular way to gauge health. Here’s why they're better than BMI.

(Image credit: Maria Fabrizio)
item.dc:creator: Allison Aubrey

item.title: How earning $30 too much a month keeps a cancer patient in Georgia from cheaper care
item.description: Georgia hasn’t expanded Medicaid. Some people suffer more than others because of that coverage gap.
item.content:encoded:
Georgia hasn’t expanded Medicaid. Some people suffer more than others because of that coverage gap.

(Image credit: Claire Harbage)
item.dc:creator: Obed Manuel

item.title: The upside-down American flag goes mainstream as a form of right-wing protest
item.description: The symbol, traditionally used by seafarers as a distress call, has been wielded as a bipartisan protest. But its most visible recent uses have taken a hard right political shift.
item.content:encoded:
The symbol, traditionally used by seafarers as a distress call, has been wielded as a bipartisan protest. But its most visible recent uses have taken a hard right political shift.

(Image credit: Jose Luis Magana)
item.dc:creator: Emma Bowman

item.title: Can you make music from Joshua trees — or is that wild science? Yes.
item.description: Scientists have long studied how near-infrared light bounces off forests and grasslands, as a proxy for plant health. Now, an artist is using the same trick to turn the Joshua tree into an instrument.
item.content:encoded:
Scientists have long studied how near-infrared light bounces off forests and grasslands, as a proxy for plant health. Now, an artist is using the same trick to turn the Joshua tree into an instrument.

(Image credit: Carlos Jaramillo for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Christopher Intagliata

item.title: What to make of the new COVID variants, FLiRT
item.description: As much as we would all love to ignore COVID, a new set of variants that scientists call “FLiRT” is here to remind us that the virus is still with us.
item.content:encoded:
As much as we would all love to ignore COVID, a new set of variants that scientists call “FLiRT” is here to remind us that the virus is still with us.

(Image credit: Justin Sullivan)
item.dc:creator: Ailsa Chang

item.title: A priest honors the nun who demonstrated 'the ministry of presence'
item.description: When Father James Martin's dad was dying, a nun named Sister Janice Farnham went out of her way to visit him.
item.content:encoded:
When Father James Martin's dad was dying, a nun named Sister Janice Farnham went out of her way to visit him.

(Image credit: James Martin.)
item.dc:creator: Laura Kwerel

item.title: This chef in Rwanda wants to create a revolution in African cuisine
item.description: Meza Malonga, a restaurant in Rwanda's capital Kigali, serves innovative Afro-fusion cuisine. Chef Dieuveil Malonga opened it in 2020, after years of working in high-end European restaurants.
item.content:encoded: Meza Malonga, a restaurant in Rwanda's capital Kigali, serves innovative Afro-fusion cuisine. Chef Dieuveil Malonga opened it in 2020, after years of working in high-end European restaurants.
item.dc:creator: Matt Ozug

item.title: Georgia's parliament speaker signs divisive foreign influence bill into law
item.description: Opponents have denounced the legislation as "the Russian law" because it resembles measures pushed through by the Kremlin to crack down on independent news media, nonprofits and activists.
item.content:encoded:
Opponents have denounced the legislation as "the Russian law" because it resembles measures pushed through by the Kremlin to crack down on independent news media, nonprofits and activists.

(Image credit: Zurab Tsertsvadze)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
